prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about splitting bills with a girlfriend. The guy writes on Reddit, asking if he's wrong to make his girlfriend start paying some bills after an incident where she had to pay for takeout because he forgot his wallet.

First, I need to break down the situation. They live together. He pays all the bills, she's part-time. The issue arose when he made her pay for takeout, and her reaction was negative. He feels she should start contributing more, even if she can't cover a lot. He's upset about her attitude and wants her to carry her weight, even out of principle.

So, the main points are: financial responsibilities in a relationship, communication, and expectations. The guy is taking her reaction personally and feels justified in changing the arrangement after one incident. But is he in the wrong?

Well, in relationships, splitting costs can be a sensitive topic. He's been paying everything until now. Maybe he never discussed expectations beforehand. If he didn't talk about it, then making a sudden change after one incident might be unfair. His reaction is based on a single event where she was upset, but maybe she's not used to contributing yet. 

Also, her part-time job might mean she has limited income. Even if he's the primary earner, expecting her to pay some bills could be reasonable, but the timing and approach matter. He's reacting out of frustration from a small incident, which might not be the best way to handle it. Communication is key here. Instead of making her pay because of a $40 takeout, maybe a discussion about shared responsibilities would be better.

The question is whether he's in the wrong. If he's being abrupt and making a big change over a minor issue without prior discussion, that could be problematic. The fact that he's focused on her attitude towards a small amount might indicate he's overreacting. But if he feels the financial arrangement isn't fair long-term, there's some validity to his point. However, the way he's handling it—using a single incident to demand changes—might be the issue. So the answer would likely be A (Yes, he's in the wrong) because he's making a unilateral decision based on a minor event without considering her perspective or discussing shared responsibilities beforehand.
